titleStmt.title: Man, before the rage of
a machine readable transcription

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: Although they are written in free verse, both the conventional nature of these lines and the handwriting suggest an early date of inscription. This draft may be a continuation of "There is no word in," suggesting it may relate to the poem eventually titled "Song of Myself." The lines, especially the first and third, also bear some resemblance to a passage of the preface to the 1855 Leaves of Grass and to lines in what eventually became section 6 of "I Sing the Body Electric."

note.p: This manuscript may be a continuation of "There is no word in," which relates to lines in the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass that ultimately became sections 48 and 49 of the poem titled "Song of Myself."

Lines 1 and 3 of this manuscript are possibly related to the following passage in the preface to the 1855 Leaves of Grass: "What do you think is the grandeur of storms and dismemberments and the deadliest battles and wrecks and the wildest fury of the elements and the power of the sea and the motion of nature and of the throes of human desires and dignity and hate and love?" (1855, p. vii).
Lines 1 and 3 of this manuscript are possibly related to lines in the fifth poem of the first edition of Leaves of Grass, eventually titled "I Sing the Body Electric."

bibl.author: Whitman, Walt
bibl.title: Man, before the rage of whose passions
bibl.orgName: Papers of Walt Whitman (MSS 3829), Clifton Waller Barrett Library of American Literature, Albert H. Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

lg.l:
Man, before the rage of whose passions
the storms of Heaven are but a breath;

Before whose caprices the lightning is
slow and less fatal:

Man, microcosm of all Creation's wildness,
terror, beauty and power,

And whose folly and wickedness are in
nothing else existent.â€”
